description: This course covers the finance of technological innovation, with a focus on the valuation tools useful in the venture capital industry. These tools include the "venture capital method," comparables analysis, discounted cash flow analysis, Monte Carlo simulation, contingent-claims analysis, decision trees, and real options. The primary audience for this course is finance majors interested in careers in venture capital or in R&D-intensive companies in health care or information technology.
name: VENT CAP & FNCE INNOVAT

values.comments:
This course covers the finance of technological innovation, with a focus on the valuation tools useful in the venture capital industry. These tools include the "venture capital method," comparables analysis, discounted cash flow analysis, Monte Carlo simulation, contingent-claims analysis, decision trees, and real options. The primary audience for this course is finance majors interested in careers in venture capital or in R&D-intensive companies in health care or information technology.

Student feedback on course content and on the course as a whole was generally very strong. One student commented, “The blend of theory and real-world application was exceptional and highly accretive to the learning process.” Another student affirmed, “This was the highest quality, most knowledge-gaining class I have taken at Wharton thus far.” A few students thought that course material was too basic for an upper-level finance class.

Students described Professor Wessels as “energetic,” “engaging,” “personable,” and “phenomenal.” Many praised his lecturing ability and capacity to explain the “deeper reasoning” behind the basic assumptions of finance. One student stated that the professor’s lectures were “lively, inviting, and quite interesting,” and went on to say that class material was engaging for “seasoned finance students and newbies” alike. 

Some expressed that the exams did not test the students’ knowledge of the core course material, but rather focused on “peripherally related material.” Others were displeased with the grading system and would have liked to have more resources available for exam preparation. Several students suggested that more case work would have been preferable.
